title: Companies Wrestle With What to Disclose About Coronavirus Risks
summary: Challenge lies in disclosing details of future impact in financial filings, when information about the current outbreak is evolving. Companies are puzzling over what to tell investors about how the still-developing global coronavirus outbreak could affect future performance.

title: Air Transport Communications Company Settles Allegations of Terrorist Sanctions Violations
summary: Société Internationale de Télécommunications Aéronautiques SCRL agrees to pay $7.8 million to settle allegations it did business with airlines that the U.S. had placed on a terrorist blacklist. An air transport communications company has agreed to pay $7.8 million to settle allegations it did business with airlines that the U.S. had placed on a terrorist blacklist.

title: CFOs, Ratings Firms Keep Close Eye on Liquidity, Cash Flow as Coronavirus Spreads
summary: Companies could face ratings downgrades and funding problems amid continued outbreak. Finance chiefs and ratings firms are ramping up their efforts to assess the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on companies' balance sheets, cash flow and liquidity buffers.

title: Marriott Predicts Coronavirus Will Hurt Fee Revenue
summary: Travel disruptions and low Asia-Pacific occupancy rates pose threat to hotel operator's results. Marriott International Inc. expects the coronavirus epidemic to weigh on its fee revenue in 2020, as the pathogen's spread outside of China stokes fears and disrupts travel.

title: Global Airlines Brace for Coronavirus Impact
summary: Epidemic might cost sector as much as $100 billion, some experts say. As coronavirus continues its spread outside of China, the global airline industry is recalibrating its response to a threat that could be its worst since the financial crisis a decade ago.

title: Microsoft Expects Personal Computing to Miss Target
summary: Unit's products include Windows software, Surface tablets and Xbox gaming hardware. Microsoft Corp. warned that supply-chain disruptions from the coronavirus outbreak would dent this quarter's sales, the second major tech company after Apple Inc. to lower expectations because of the public-health crisis in China.

title: Colorado Legislature Repeals Death Penalty
summary: Gov. Jared Polis is expected to sign the bill, making Colorado the 10th state since 2004 to abolish capital punishment. Colorado is poised to become the latest state to abolish capital punishment after the state's Democratic-controlled Legislature approved a repeal of the state's death penalty on Wednesday.

title: Coronavirus Spreads Outside of Italy, Prompting Fresh Restrictions
summary: Cases of the virus cross the Alps to emerge in Switzerland, Germany and Spain's Canary Islands. Italy's coronavirus outbreak has crossed the Alps and is being linked to a growing number of infections around Europe, prompting countries and companies to enact precautionary measures to reduce travel to and from Italy as the number of fatalities clicked higher.

title: House Judiciary Panel Pulls FISA Intelligence Bill Before Vote
summary: Measure to extend expiring surveillance powers and impose new curbs collapses due to opposition from privacy advocates. WASHINGTON-The House Judiciary Committee canceled a vote on an extension of key intelligence powers after a bipartisan coalition called for broader restrictions on government surveillance than what the bill contained.

title: The NFL Nears Labor Peace After Tension and Angst
summary: Player leaders took a critical step toward completing a new collective bargaining agreement that could add a 17th game to the regular season. INDIANAPOLIS-The NFL and its players are on the verge of agreeing to a new, decade-long collective bargaining agreement after a tense sequence of events over the past week that left the billionaires who run the league anxious and the millionaires who play inside it preparing for the possibility of a labor war.

title: The SASB Doesn't Work for Mike Bloomberg
summary: The Sustainability Accounting Standards Board is not pursuing Michael Bloomberg's-or anyone's-policy agenda.. Regarding your editorial "Bloomberg's Business Nanny" (Feb. 18) on the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board: The SASB is not pursuing Michael Bloomberg's-or anyone's-policy agenda. Furthermore, the SASB has always believed that "materiality judgments can properly be made only by those that understand the reporting entity's pertinent facts and circumstances," which is why we encourage companies to consider and assess for themselves each topic in the SASB standard for their industry or industries. When a company determines that a sustainability topic is financially material to its business, SASB's voluntary standards offer a way to standardize disclosure on that topic for the benefit of both companies and investors.

title: Solar Power Grows, but Market Share Is Low
summary: Solar's total installed gigawatts may surpass other electric-power sources as early as 2035, but photovoltaic technology still will lag far behind fossil fuels in the electricity it actually produces.. "Cheap Solar Power Challenges Coal's Dominance in India" (Page One, Feb. 18) may invite undue complacency about solar power's capabilities. According to the International Energy Agency, solar's total installed gigawatts may surpass other electric-power sources as early as 2035, but photovoltaic technology still will lag far behind fossil fuels in the electricity it actually produces. This is because solar has a "capacity factor," or average level of electricity generation relative to maximum technical output, that is much lower than other fuel sources. The IEA estimates that solar has a capacity factor of 10% to 21%. For natural-gas plants, the range is several times higher. Based on this and other differences, the IEA's "stated policies" scenario estimates that coal and natural gas will still be producing about 45% of the world's electricity by 2040, while solar will supply only about 11%.

title: Treasury Yields Hit Fresh Record Lows; Energy Bonds Slide
summary: Government-bond rally lifts most investment-grade corporate debt. U.S. government-bond yields, reversing Wednesday's early rise, were dragged down to fresh all-time lows amid new signs that the coronavirus is spreading.

title: We Are Volunteers in Mike Bloomberg's Army
summary: None of us was asked to start these social-media groups for the campaign nor do we take direction or receive payment from the campaign.. Regarding "Bloomberg Hires Social-Media Army" (U.S. News, Feb. 20): Mike Bloomberg has thousands of volunteer grass-roots supporters who are creating and participating in online communities on Facebook without payment. Volunteers stepped up to create or manage Facebook groups in support of Mike's candidacy before the campaign had any state or local online presence. Our goal is to foster positive online communities that enable Bloomberg supporters and the "Bloomberg-curious" to connect with each other, ask questions and share information.

title: Bernie Needs to Come Clean On His Health Records Now
summary: How can anyone feel comfortable voting for a 78-year-old U.S. presidential candidate who recently had a heart attack corrected by "doctors reopening the blocked coronary artery and placing two drug-eluting stents.". Regarding your editorial "Bernie's Medical Stonewall" (Feb. 21): I am an 80-year-old, fee-based physician working at the Military Entrance Processing Station in Phoenix. Interviews and physical examinations are done on all military applicants 17-40 years of age. If there have been any medical issues in an applicant's life, the Defense Department requires the release of all past medical records for review before accepting the applicant for enlistment in the military. A personal letter from his doctor alone is not acceptable.

title: Canada Warns of Freight-Rail Delays of 'Many Weeks'
summary: Protest blockades could detract from Canada's first-quarter economic growth. OTTAWA-Canada's Transport Minister said Wednesday the country was "many, many weeks" away from a return to normal for freight-rail traffic, after police this week dismantled a blockade that had choked off shipments from east to west.

title: Gilead to Kick Off Its Own Studies of Potential Coronavirus Drug
summary: Drugmaker-sponsored studies could be basis for approval of a new antiviral drug, after researchers in China and U.S. also have begun trials. title: Coronavirus Infection: DHS Should First Do No Harm
summary: All passengers processed from my Taipei flight had to use the same fingerprint touch screen.. Regarding Holman Jenkins's "Coronavirus Needs a Free Press" (Business World, Feb. 12): Landing at Houston's international airport recently, I found 14 immigration isles, but only one was open. There was no hand sanitizer and no staff even occasionally cleaning it.

title: For Wine Expertise, Who Can You Really Trust?
summary: As sommeliers have grown more visible in popular culture, the definition of the role has been stretched to the breaking point. Who actually deserves the title?. The guest looked disappointed-clearly my job didn't command the same respect. Knowing how hard sommeliers work, I could hardly blame her.

summary: Oxtail brings incredible richness to these recipes and it's all but impossible to get wrong. In fact, the best thing you can do with this cut is leave it alone for a good long time.. For starters, "oxtail" is a misnomer: The tail does not necessarily come from an ox; it can be obtained from any kind of cattle. Then there's the assumption that because a tail works hard (swatting flies, etc.), its meat will have a tough, chewy texture. Not so, if you prepare it correctly.

title: This Is No Time to Go Wobbly on Capitalism
summary: As Democrats embrace outright socialism, some CEOs and Republicans call for unwise compromises.. There's an important debate happening in America right now, a competition among three distinct views of the world. The first view is held by those who think capitalism is the best and fairest economic system the world has ever seen. The second is held by those who think socialism is the answer to a host of problems from climate change to inequality. Then there are those who are pushing a watered-down or hyphenated capitalism, which is the slow path to socialism.

A stainless steel Rolex Submariner will set you back $7,900, but a pink gold Roger Dubuis Excalibur rings in at $76,000. title: A New Peter Pan Tale Is All About 'Wendy'

She waits for them to return from their adventures and tucks them into bed at night. In the new movie "Wendy," however, she is as wild as they are.

title: Furniture With Skirts: Why This Old Idea Is Taking Off Again
summary: Cloaking a piece in fabric-once a favorite gambit of the cash-strapped-can dress up as well as cover up. OLD-SCHOOL guides to "frugal" decorating invariably featured a homey tip: Wrap a flaw-concealing "skirt" around rusted sink basins to approximate a bathroom vanity, or cloak troubling table legs to elevate entry-hall furniture. This crafty strategy was typically executed with a sad remnant of cotton and fell short of elegance-more "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" than "The Crown."

title: Coronavirus Cruise Captain and Crew on the Lockdown: 'The Rulebook Was Thrown Out'
summary: Staff took on new jobs as the quarantine began, organizing medicines, getting the sick onto ambulances, supporting passengers in hospitals. TOKYO-When the Diamond Princess wrapped up its two-week cruise and sailed back into Yokohama on Feb. 3, three helicopters circled above and Japanese health officials climbed on board. Capt. title: A Darkly Handsome Bolthole in London's Kennington Neighborhood
summary: Simon Holloway, the creative director of Italian heritage brand Agnona, has crafted his dream home in London. All I ever wanted to do as a teenager was move to London and wear black clothes," says Simon Holloway, 48, who hails from Newcastle, in England's northeast corner. Today, the creative director of Italian fashion house Agnona doesn't quite restrict his wardrobe to onyx, obsidian and ebony, but the teenage Holloway would likely approve of his darkly handsome bolthole in London's Kennington neighborhood. "Even though now I spend a lot of time in Milan, I make a point of telling everyone that I live in London," he says.

title: What Theater Director Ivo van Hove Can't Live Without
summary: The renowned force behind the 'West Side Story' revival shares a few cherished objects, from a David Bowie gift to his favored (and perfectly sharpened) pencil. "Near the front, New York University notebooks with pencil, sharpener and refillable orange marker. I use about one notebook a year, and I keep them all because they sometimes become inspirations for new productions. The idea for the revival of West Side Story was in my 2016 book. Also, on the table, my Terre d'Hermès perfume. I don't use a lot-three drops in the morning-but everywhere everybody says, 'Oh, you smell good.' I'm working with people all day, very near to them. I'm not the kind of director who sits behind a table. To the right, the shirt, that's my uniform, always dark blue or black. The yellow object near the front is Wall-E. It has been in our home for a long time and has a prominent place. Nobody understands it. But Wall-E breaks my heart. Near the perfume, Paul Smith rocket cuff links, a gift from David Bowie on the eve of the opening night of Lazarus. These rockets are symbolic of what his dreams were. On the right, Joni Mitchell's Blue CD. She really opened up about who she was, what her worries were, all these doubts I had myself when I was 15, 16 years old, even the doubts that I still have. On the left, my hard drive, mostly full of movies. I have no hobbies, not one, except for going to the movies. In the back left, Jan [Versweyveld, van Hove's partner] made this table lamp when he was 19. It's traveled with us from every house that we've lived in, and it's still there, more than 42 years later-as long as we've been together. The photo in the back is from when we were 20, at the end of the '70s. I look at how different we were, but I see we are still a little bit the same. On the right, my fryer. I'm the worst cook in the world. I invite my actors to my home in Amsterdam, and I fry real Belgian fries. That's the only thing I can do in the kitchen and do it well."

title: Bayer Chairman Steps Down in Midst of Roundup Legal Battle
summary: Werner Wenning is set to be replaced by Norbert Winkeljohann as the company attempts to resolve thousands of lawsuits. BERLIN- Bayer AG , in the midst of a major legal battle over its Roundup herbicide, said Chairman Werner Wenning would step down earlier than planned and be replaced by a former PricewaterhouseCoopers executive who joined the German company's board in 2018.

title: The High Spirits of A$AP Rocky

"I did a front flip into the crowd last night-and landed on this kid's head," he explains, wincing as he limps across the floorboards of Jimi Hendrix's old studio.

title: 'They Become Part of Me': Readers Share Their Secrets to Lifelong Friendships

After The Wall Street Journal published an interview with Lydia Denworth, author of a new book on the science of friendship, readers shared stories of the relationships that bring meaning to their lives.

title: The Car Industry's Big Merger Is Better Than Investors Think
summary: PSA's 2019 financial results show why its tie-up with Fiat Chrysler could offer decent profit growth even against a tough backdrop. Investors have been disappointed too often to give car manufacturers much advance credit for cost-cutting plans. In the case of the industry's big merger, that may create an opportunity for those that dare to break ranks.

title: RV Living Grows as Latest Consequence of Housing Crisis
summary: Resume Subscription. MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.-The RVs started arriving on Continental Circle about four years ago. Now they line one side of the half-mile-long street in this Silicon Valley suburb.

title: The Pros Have to Sell Stocks Now. You Don't.
summary: Small investors who resist the coronavirus fears sweeping the market could be in position to buy bargains as big money flees. When markets crumple, the culprits usually aren't the smallest investors, but the biggest.

title: Blackstone Bets Big on U.K. Student Housing, Acquiring IQ for $6 Billion
summary: Acquisition comes as early signs point to revival in European deal-making. Blackstone Group Inc. agreed Wednesday to acquire IQ Student Accommodation from a group led by Goldman Sachs Group Inc. for £4.66 billion ($6.06 billion) including debt, the latest bet by the U.S. buyout giant on the growth of student housing in the U.K.

title: Salesforce Co-CEO Block Steps Down
summary: Executive change came as Salesforce reported quarterly earnings swung to a net loss of $248 million. Salesforce . com Inc. said Co-Chief Executive Keith Block is stepping down from his role, just 18 months after taking the job, ending for now a brief experiment with dual CEOs and leaving Marc Benioff in charge of the business-software provider.

title: Health Insurance Stocks Lose Immunity
summary: A great investment for a decade, the industry faces virus-related and political risks. Health insurance has offered some of the best investment opportunities of the past decade. The prognosis, however, now looks shaky.

title: BlackRock's Barbara Novick Is Stepping Down
summary: Co-founder of investment giant built a Washington lobbying machine. Barbara Novick, who turned BlackRock Inc. into a force in Washington, is stepping down.

title: NBCUniversal Opens New Local Ads Business for Streaming TV
summary: The company plans to hire up to 20 staffers for a new local ads business tasked with tackling the surging local TV streaming ads category. Comcast Corp.'s NBCUniversal is launching a new streaming advertising business for its local TV stations group as viewers and advertisers continue to shift to internet-connected programming.

title: As Investors Cast Off Coal Stakes, Miners Rely on a Few Big Funds
summary: Changing ESG standards leave mining companies exposed to a handful of investment funds. Two of the world's largest investment funds have begun selling down stakes in coal miners citing environmental concerns, leaving shares of some of the companies concentrated in the hands of a few large U.S. investors.

title: U.S. Forces Return to Saudi Arabia to Deter Attacks by Iran
summary: Resume Subscription. PRINCE SULTAN AIR BASE, Saudi Arabia-Nearly 17 years after U.S. troops largely pulled up stakes from the kingdom, the U.S. is now back in force.

title: AI Comes to the Tax Code
summary: Governments turn to machine learning to boost revenue as taxpayers seek to reduce their bills. IRVINE, Calif.-Tax cheats, beware: The machines are watching.

title: Coronavirus in China Threatens Amazon Sellers
summary: Saying Amazon's rankings algorithm demotes products that are out of stock, many are raising prices to slow sales, looking to shift production. Thousands of Amazon.com Inc. sellers who built their businesses using China's cheap and efficient manufacturers are on the spot as the coronavirus shuts factories there.

title: Can Supply Chains Survive the Coronavirus? China, the U.S. and Germany Are Key
summary: Whether the infectious disease spreads to other countries that make hard-to-replace products may be the acid test of its impact on global manufacturing this year. This is the second column in a five part Heard on the Street series about the market and economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic.

title: Stocks to Watch: Disney, Salesforce, Mattel, Toll Brothers
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours.

title: Hong Kong, Hit by Coronavirus and Protests, to Hand Out Billions of Dollars in Cash
summary: As economy reels, an "exceptional measure" is necessary to encourage consumer spending, said Financial Secretary Paul Chan. Hong Kong's government said it would dole out $15.4 billion in cash payouts and other stimulus in its annual budget in an attempt to resuscitate an economy reeling from the coronavirus epidemic and months of antigovernment protests.

title: The Painful Problem With Pandemic Bonds
summary: The asset class is uncorrelated with wider markets-except at the exact moment when that matters most. As the coronavirus that began in the Chinese city of Wuhan spreads rapidly around the world, pandemic bonds designed to assist poor countries in financing their response are on the verge of being triggered for the first time.

title: Coronavirus Epidemic Threatens Rio Tinto's Supply Chain
summary: The miner reports a 41% decline in annual net profit. Rio Tinto PLC warned the coronavirus epidemic is threatening its supply chain as it reported a 41% decline in annual net profit, but said it would pay a record final dividend.

title: Hindus, Muslims Clash Over India Citizenship Law
summary: Deadly violence erupts as President Trump and first lady participate in events elsewhere in city without incident. NEW DELHI-At least 20 people died and hundreds were injured in India's capital as clashes between protesters and supporters of a controversial new law devolved into sectarian violence between groups of Hindus and Muslims.

title: Rivals Focus on Sanders at South Carolina Debate
summary: Raucous exchanges mark the event as candidates position themselves before delegate-rich contests. Sen. Bernie Sanders bore the brunt of the attacks from his presidential rivals during a cacophonous debate that highlighted his rival candidates' anxiety over the possibility of a self-described democratic socialist facing President Trump in November.

title: Bloomberg's Second Debate: Steadier, but Still Bumpy
summary: The former New York mayor delivered a smoother performance than in Nevada, though he had some awkward moments. CHARLESTON, S.C.-The questions were similar, as were his eye rolls, but Michael Bloomberg had some answers this time.

title: MPM Capital Raises $100 Million Fund, Teams Up With Dana-Farber Cancer Institute
summary: Collaboration seeks to promote cancer research, new biotech companies. Health-care investor MPM Capital has raised a $100 million venture-capital fund through a new collaboration with Boston's Dana-Farber Cancer Institute aimed at promoting cancer research and new oncology-drug startups.

title: The Most Delicious Way to Cook Cauliflower
summary: Roast half of it for deep umami flavor and give the rest a quick simmer to keep it delightfully vital. The result is a satisfying vegetable ragout to serve over pasta. ON DAYS OFF, most chefs want to be anywhere but the kitchen. Philip Krajeck is an exception. "I'm a dad and I love to cook," he said. While you won't find this warming winter pasta on the menu at either of Mr. Krajeck's Nashville restaurants, it wins rave reviews from his family. His second Slow Food Fast recipe combines rigatoni with cauliflower, anchovies, chile flakes, garlic and Parmesan. Fresh parsley and crunchy fried breadcrumbs provide color and contrast.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Democratic Debate in South Carolina: The Moments That Mattered
summary: Seven candidates sought to make their points in sharp exchanges during the final debate before Super Tuesday. CHARLESTON, S.C.-Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, days after a resounding victory in the Nevada caucuses, took the bulk of incoming fire on the debate stage here ahead of this state's Saturday primary.

title: Hello, World!
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Florida's Latino Democrats Decry Bernie Sanders's Cuba Comments as Candidate Digs In
summary: Important swing state is home to generations of voters who fled Cuba, Nicaragua, Venezuela. MIAMI-Sen. Bernie Sanders's recent comments on Cuba have drawn condemnation in Latino-heavy Florida and fanned some Democrats' fears that he would doom their chances of winning the swing state if he is the party's presidential nominee.

title: Ten-Year-Old Girl Killed By New York City School Bus
summary: Pedestrian deaths have climbed in city so far this year; 'We are devastated,' girl's charter-school network says. A 10-year-old girl was hit and killed by a yellow school bus in Brooklyn on Tuesday morning as she tried to cross the street, police said.

title: CDC Warns It Expects Coronavirus to Spread in U.S.
summary: Official says authorities are preparing for a potential pandemic; Trump administration's response is challenged in Congress. Federal health authorities said Tuesday they now expect a wider spread of the coronavirus in the U.S. and are preparing for a potential pandemic, though they remain unsure about how severe the health threat could be.

title: Trump Teases a New Media Strategy
summary: Meanwhile Sanders proposes an economic revolution.. There's an argument that people don't change all that much after the age of 70. But at a Tuesday press conference in India, President Donald Trump suggested that he intends to be more careful with his words. Whether or not Mr. Trump alters his speaking style, flaws in his communication look less consequential when one considers the agenda of the leading candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination. A new critique of the Bernie Sanders economic plan could make people almost forget that Mr. Trump ever tweeted.

title: Order in the Mouse House
summary: Disney's 'surprise' CEO news wasn't much of a surprise. Perhaps the only genuine surprise Walt Disney Co. sprang on investors Tuesday afternoon was the name of its new chief executive. Even that wasn't much of a surprise.

title: New Cases Drop in China as Virus Spreads Globally
summary: With pace of new cases slowing, several Chinese provinces lower their health-alert levels. BEIJING-The number of new coronavirus cases in China dropped dramatically in recent days outside the province at the center of the epidemic, but health authorities raised alarms about sharp increases in infections elsewhere in the world.

title: South Korea Plans 'Maximum' Quarantine Steps in Coronavirus-Struck City
summary: Visiting epicenter, president calls the next several days a 'clear inflection point'. South Korea's president visited a virus-stricken city and called the next several days a "clear inflection point," as the government said it would investigate the roughly 200,000 followers of a mysterious religious sect linked with most of the country's cases.

title: Virgin Galactic Plans to Resume Space-Tourism Sales
summary: Company backed by Richard Branson says it has secured 20 of 29 necessary approvals from FAA. Virgin Galactic Holdings Inc. still plans to make its first commercial space-tourism flight this year and took a step toward resuming ticket sales for jaunts expected to cost upward of $250,000.

title: Univision Sells to Group Led by Ex-Viacom Executive for Less Than $10 Billion
summary: Mexican media company Grupo Televisa to retain 36% stake. Univision Communications Inc. agreed to sell a majority stake to a bidding group that includes former Viacom finance chief Wade Davis and private-equity firm Searchlight Capital Partners, ending a long period of uncertainty over the fate of the Spanish-language broadcaster.

title: Coronavirus Infections Grow in Italy
summary: Death toll stands at 11 as experts warn the global spread of Covid-19 is reaching a tipping point. MILAN-Italy's coronavirus outbreak continued to spread, bucking efforts to contain it mostly to two rural areas near Milan and Venice. New cases appeared as far south as Sicily, showing the limits of quarantining towns and the difficulties facing health officials.

title: Jurors Questioned in Roger Stone Case
summary: Trump confidant has requested a new trial citing misconduct by jury forewoman. Jurors from the trial of Roger Stone testified in court Tuesday that they faced no pressure in their deliberations and each came to their conclusions independently, as the legal drama surrounding the case continued and Mr. Stone sought to convince a federal judge he deserves a new trial.

title: The Spending Virus
summary: Congress shows political opportunism with another health plague.. Federal health officials warned Tuesday that the new coronavirus will spread much more than it has in the U.S., and financial investors continued their repricing down of assets as a result. Equities fell another 3% or so. Politicians, meanwhile, were repricing upward their chances of another burst of new federal spending.

title: Retail Tycoon Resigns After Raid in Sex-Trafficking Probe
summary: Canadian fashion executive Peter Nygard, denying allegations, steps down from company amid federal investigation. Canadian retail tycoon Peter Nygard stepped down as chairman of his company after federal and local authorities raided the firm's Manhattan offices as part of an investigation into sex-trafficking allegations against him.

title: The Federal Judges' Mystery Meeting
summary: A judicial group should set the record straight about its 'emergency.'. Donald Trump's Twitter outbursts over the sentencing of Roger Stone were inappropriate and self-defeating. But the most disturbing part of the Stone saga was reporting last week that the Federal Judges Association leadership had scheduled "an emergency meeting" to rebuke the President. That suggested the judiciary was mobilizing politically-a prospect that delighted the resistance to Mr. Trump but is a danger to the rule of law.

title: March Primary Madness
summary: Early voting and other changes may create a vote-counting mess.. Fourteen states hold primaries next Tuesday, but millions of votes will already have been cast for those contests. Democrats over the years have pushed to expand early voting to help their candidates, but they may soon rue the results. Super Crazy March is possible.

title: Mastercard's Next CEO to Continue Company's Push Beyond Cards
summary: Michael Miebach will become president on March 1, then chief executive next January. Mastercard Inc.'s pick for its next chief executive puts more muscle behind the company's effort to expand beyond its legacy cards business.

title: The Virus Response Spurs Hong Kong's Labor Movement
summary: Hospital workers staged a five-day strike demanding a total shutdown of the border with the mainland.. The novel coronavirus has diverted attention from Hong Kong's fight for democracy, but it has also helped feed the movement. As of Feb. 25, the territory had 81 cumulative confirmed coronavirus cases and two deaths. Dissatisfaction with the way Chief Executive Carrie Lam has handled the outbreak has contributed to the rapid growth of labor unions, which play an increasingly central role in the opposition to Chinese Communist rule.

title: Wealthy Americans Already Pay Their Share
summary: Arguments to the contrary spurn or wildly distort statistics and cherry-pick anecdotal examples.. Even amid a freewheeling presidential primary, Democrats are of one mind when it comes to taxation: Rich Americans are not paying their fair share. Congressional Democrats have joined the debate, proposing a 10% surcharge on incomes above $2 million. Once imposed, the Democratic tax wish list could quickly grow into a massive drain on American families-much as the income tax grew in its first 50 years. What began in 1913 as a mere 7% levy on earnings above $500,000 (almost $13 million in 2019 dollars) rose by 1963 to a 72% tax on incomes above $44,000.

title: Obama Did Persecute For-Profit Colleges
summary: Lots of nonprofit programs flunk the Gainful Employment rules he imposed.. Some on the left scapegoat for-profit colleges for the problems of higher education. The Obama administration crafted a set of "Gainful Employment" regulations primarily targeting these programs. If a pool of graduates had too much debt relative to earnings, the government would cut off financial aid to its students. These and other regulations helped drive a sharp decline in for-profit enrollment. But new data released by the Education Department reveals just how misguided these policies were.

title: Sanders Takes Up McGovern's Mantle
summary: And as in 1972, a far-left platform could doom the Democratic presidential ticket.. A badly split political party nominates an unpopular establishment-wing presidential candidate, who proceeds to lose the general election. The other party's equally unpopular nominee wins more than 300 electoral votes despite falling far short of a popular-vote majority. The defeated party's insurgent wing then succeeds in rewriting the party's rules to its advantage, and an antiestablishment candidate wins the presidential nomination-only to suffer one of the worst landslide losses in American political history.

title: How Bezos Can Influence Climate
summary: His 'just do it' approach to space travel can also be used to cool the planet.. Jeff Bezos' $10 billion commitment to fight climate change, which he announced last week, brings to mind an episode of "South Park" that aired during the financial crisis. A succession of characters put their money into the market only to see it go instantly to zero before their eyes.

title: The Democratic Establishment Will Rally Around Bernie
summary: The sins of Sanders's past will be waved away when the choice is between him and Trump.. A week from now, Bernie Sanders could well be on a glide path to the Democratic presidential nomination. Even if he doesn't win the primary in South Carolina on Saturday, he's expected to do well there. Three days later is Super Tuesday, when 14 states will hold contests and more than a third of the national delegates will be awarded.

title: What Bloomberg's Money Can't Buy
summary: A deep connection with voters, a new reputation and Americans' votes, students argue.. Editor's note: This Future View is about Mike Bloomberg's record levels of spending on his campaign for the Democratic nomination for president. For next week we'll ask, "Have the #MeToo movement and the national focus on sexual assault and harassment affected your campus?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before March 3. The best responses will be published that night.

title: 'Operation Chastise' Review: Myth-Busting the Dam Busters
summary: The attack on Germany's dams during World War II has been immortalized in popular ﬁlm and legend. The reality is more nuanced.. A few years ago, I happened to be speaking with the legendary Capt. Eric "Winkle" Brown, arguably one of the greatest aviators ever, who, as a test pilot, flew a staggering 485 types of aircraft, a record that will never be broken. He once met Guy Gibson, he told me, and the two talked at some length. "Do you ever feel scared when you're flying?" Gibson suddenly asked him. Brown responded that he did not. "You're lucky," Gibson replied, admitting that "I'm absolutely terrified every time I set foot" in a plane. It was a remarkable yet very human admission from one of the most famous British pilots of World War II-a man who liked to portray himself as the ultimate "press on" bomber commander: fearless, aggressive and always cheerful in the face of adversity, ever willing to do more than what was asked of him. It was this character that Richard Todd-who had himself been a British paratrooper on D-Day-so memorably portrayed when he played Gibson in the 1955 movie "The Dam Busters." Yet as Max Hastings reveals in his fascinating and immensely readable "Operation Chastise: The RAF's Most Brilliant Attack of World War II," almost everything we think we know from the film and popular mythology is wrong.

title: SEC Investigating Mattel's Accounting
summary: The toy maker said it resolved an accounting error after an internal probe last year; SEC and federal prosecutors want a closer look. Mattel Inc. is facing fresh scrutiny over an internal probe into accounting issues that the toy maker said it resolved last year.

title: Notable & Quotable: Socialism
summary: 'We don't want simply to fight against some other political majority-we want to become the majority.'. Micah Uetricht and Meagan Day in a Feb. 22 Salon essay adapted from their forthcoming book, "Bigger than Bernie: How We Go From the Sanders Campaign to Democratic Socialism":
